DOCNAME: CASE OF JAMES, WELLS AND LEE v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: Remainder inadmissible;Violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-1 - Deprivation of liberty;Lawful arrest or detention;Article 5-1-a - Conviction);No violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-4 - Review by a court);Non-pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;George Nicolaou;Lech Garlicki;Nebojša Vučinić;Nicolas Bratza;Phillips of Worth Matravers;Vincent A. De Gaetano;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: CARDINAL . Mr PERSON was born in DATE and lives in GPE . PERSON was born in DATE and is currently in detention . Mr PERSON was born in DATE and lives in ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE , by virtue of section CARDINAL of LAW DATE ( “ the DATE LAW ) , indeterminate sentences for the public protection ( “ ORG sentences ” ) were introduced . These sentences are indeterminate sentences ( i.e. sentences of no fixed length ) , and , like sentences of life imprisonment , require the direction of ORG in order for the prisoner to be released . A minimum term which has to be served before a prisoner can be released , known as the “ tariff ” , is fixed by the sentencing judge . In cases involving ORG prisoners , it would appear that in practice the tariff fixed is generally short : in DATE following the entry into force of the provisions on ORG sentences , when the applicants in the present case were sentenced , the median tariff for ORG prisoners was DATE , and MONEY of ORG sentences imposed involved tariffs of DATE or less .

CARDINAL . When ORG sentences were first introduced , they were mandatory in all cases where an individual was convicted of a “ serious offence ” and was deemed by the sentencing judge to be at risk of committing a further “ specified offence ” . Risk was to be assumed in cases where the individual in question had previously been convicted of a “ relevant offence ” , unless the sentencing judge considered it unreasonable to conclude that there was a risk of further specified offences being committed . The terms “ serious offence ” , “ specified offence ” and “ relevant offence ” were defined in the CARDINAL Act .

CARDINAL . Pursuant to CARDINAL of ORG “ the DATE LAW ) , ORG was given the power to direct the release of indeterminate sentence prisoners to whom the section applied if it was satisfied that detention was no longer necessary for the protection of the public .

CARDINAL . The consequence of the entry into force of the legislative provisions introducing ORG sentences was that a large number of individuals were sentenced to an ORG sentence . Although it had been intended that the new provisions would be resource - neutral , it soon became clear that existing resources were insufficient and the large number of ORG prisoners swamped the system in place for dealing with those serving indeterminate sentences .

CARDINAL . The ORG scheme was subsequently amended by ORG “ the LAW ” ) to deal with the problems encountered . In particular , the ORG sentence is no longer mandatory . Further , it now only applies to cases where , if imposed , the tariff would be fixed at DATE , subject to certain limited exceptions .
CARDINAL . The domestic law , including the changes introduced by LAW , is set out in greater detail below ( see paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON pleaded guilty in ORG to unlawful wounding with intent . He had previous convictions for , among other things , battery , common assault , affray , disorderly behaviour , racially abusive behaviour and assault occasioning actual bodily harm . A pre - sentencing report dated DATE prepared by ORG referred to the offence forming part of a pattern of violence and threatening behaviour largely linked to Mr James’ excessive drinking . It recommended counselling to address alcohol and substance abuse . The sentencing judge accepted that Mr PERSON was dangerous , particularly when he drank alcohol . He was sentenced to an ORG sentence pursuant to LAW , with a tariff of DATE , less time spent on remand . His tariff therefore expired DATE and DATE after the date of sentencing .

CARDINAL . After being sentenced , Mr PERSON remained at his local prison , HMP GPE , and while there took all courses that he was able to take . The courses he completed included a short alcohol awareness course , an IT course , a first aid course and a Think First course . ORG reports indicated that he should also undertake the ORG ( Enhanced Thinking Skills ) course , the ASRO ( Addressing Substance Related Offending ) course and the CALM ( Controlling Anger and Learning to Manage it ) course , none of which were available to him at ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the chairman of ORG ( a statutory body established to monitor the welfare of prisoners ) wrote to Mr James’ solicitors saying that Mr PERSON had completed all the courses that were available to him at ORG and that he was unable to move to a first stage lifer prison to complete the rest of the courses needed for release because all the places at the first stage lifer prisons were full .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Lifer Governor at ORG wrote to Mr James’ solicitors explaining that he was CARDINAL on the first stage lifer prison waiting list . He said :

“ As you will be aware we must now treat ORG ( IPP ) sentenced prisoners as lifers and they are all serving short tariff sentences ... The massive influx of IPPs along with other sentenced lifers from our courts has inflated our lifer / ORG numbers to CARDINAL ( and increasing ) against a profiled maximum of CARDINAL . This increase above our profiles numbers , without any additional resources , has meant that we have not been able to accept anyone from our first stage waiting list for DATE .
Unfortunately , this trend shows no sign of slowing down and I can not predict when we might be able to accommodate Mr PERSON . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE Mr James’ solicitors wrote to the Secretary of ORG explaining his situation and requesting that he be transferred to a first stage lifer prison in order to complete the relevant courses , or that the courses be made available to him at ORG . The letter highlighted that Mr James’ tariff would expire in DATE and that he wished to complete the relevant courses before tariff expiry and his ORG hearing .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Lifer Governor at ORG wrote that the number of lifer / IPP prisoners had increased to CARDINAL :

“ The increase in ORG numbers and the fact that most of these individuals have come to us with short tariffs means that we now seem to do mostly report writing and are largely unable to get on with our ‘ real’ job of risk assessment and sentence planning work . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE Mr James’ case was referred to ORG in accordance with the standard procedure .
CARDINAL . The Progress Report Summary prepared for ORG by Mr James’ Indeterminate Sentences Manager at ORG , dated DATE , stated :

“ ... The ORG obviously considered Mr PERSON to be a danger to the public when it imposed an Indeterminate Sentence for Public Protection , but that risk would seem to have been reduced somewhat both by his increasing maturity and by the work he has already undertaken . A full assessment will only be done at the Sentence Planning stage , at his ORG , and the suggestion is that he is likely to need to undertake CALM and PERSON [ Prison : Addressing Substance Related Offending ] courses prior to release in order to ensure that his risk is reduced to an acceptable level . He professes himself happy to do these . ”
CARDINAL . NORP Under the heading “ Recommendation for allocation or release ” , the report continued :
“ As Mr PERSON has not as yet had his ORG or undertaken any work related to his offending , I can not with any confidence recommend him for release or for transfer to open conditions . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON applied to ORG for permission to seek judicial review of the management and treatment of prisoners by the Secretary of ORG in light of the failure to provide him with the relevant courses to address his offending behaviour .
CARDINAL . On DATE Mr James’ tariff period expired .
CARDINAL . Handing down his judgment in the judicial review proceedings on DATE , Mr Justice PERSON outlined the background to the judicial review application as follows :

“ CARDINAL . ... [ Mr James’ ] tariff expired on DATE and the result is that he is now detained solely as a result of the ORG on the basis that he is dangerous . He has therefore the right to apply to ORG for his release on the basis that he is no longer to be regarded as dangerous and that therefore the continued detention would not be justified .

CARDINAL . In order to make a meaningful submission to ORG , it was necessary that he undertake courses to seek to deal with his problems , particularly those of drink and anger management . There are such courses which are made available by the prison service . Unfortunately , the resources have not been provided to enable such courses to be provided for [ prisoners ] such as the claimant , who has a short tariff period . Indeed , he has been incarcerated at FAC , which is a local prison , and which does not have the facilities for the necessary courses . He has , as I understand it , undertaken a short course in relation to alcohol and an equally short one in relation to anger management but it is recognised that they would be likely to be insufficient to provide the necessary information to ORG and ORG would be likely to be in the same position as the ORG was in the case of ORG ( which was dealt with by ORG together with PERSON ) . In that case , ORG , when PERSON , who was a post - tariff prisoner , came before it , commented that he had not undertaken any offence focused work , which was not his fault because he wanted to do so , but it was not the remit of ORG to make up the deficiencies of the prison service and , because he had not been able to do any of the appropriate courses , he was unable to demonstrate any reduction in risk from the time that he was sentenced . That , PERSON ORG [ counsel for Mr PERSON ] submits , is likely to be the approach of ORG , before whom the claimant at the moment has a hearing fixed , as I understand it , for DATE . ”

CARDINAL . PERSON , relying on the decision of ORG in PERSON v. the Secretary of ORG ( “ Walker ” – see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) , declared Mr James’ detention unlawful and ordered his release , but stayed relief pending an appeal by the Secretary of ORG . He did not decide on Mr James’ argument that there had been a violation of LAW as a result of the failure to provide the courses , although he recognised the possible force of the argument and indicated that it would be “ desirable ” for ORG to consider it .
CARDINAL . NORP The Secretary of ORG appealed the decision of PERSON

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG convened to consider Mr James’ case . His representative applied for a deferral of the hearing on the grounds that the absence of a satisfactory life sentence plan and the non - availability of relevant offending behaviour courses meant that ORG would be unable to carry out a sufficiently informed risk assessment to decide whether the test for release was satisfied , referring to the conclusions of ORG in the case of PERSON ( see paragraph DATE below ) and in the case of PERSON . He further advised ORG that the case of PERSON was pending before ORG . In the circumstances ORG agreed that the hearing before it would serve no useful purpose and directed that the hearing be deferred until after the determination of the appeal in Mr James’ case and in the case of PERSON . ORG hearing was re - listed for DATE .
CARDINAL . The Court of Appeal heard the appeal in Mr James’ case together with the appeal in ORG in DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON was transferred to ORG , a first stage prison .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG allowed in part the appeal of the Secretary of ORG in Mr James’ case , holding that his continued detention following the expiry of his tariff was not unlawful in light of the express terms of section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act and section CARDINAL of LAW , which rendered detention lawful until ORG was satisfied that he was no longer dangerous ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL - CARDINAL below ) ; and that the detention would not cease to be justified under LAW ( a ) of the LAW until it was no longer necessary for the protection of the public that Mr PERSON be detained or so long had elapsed without a meaningful review of the question that the detention had become disproportionate or arbitrary . However , it upheld the declaration made in PERSON that the Secretary of ORG had breached his public law duty .

CARDINAL . Lord PERSON of Worth Matravers CJ , delivering the judgment of the court , considered the primary object of the ORG sentence to be clear from the wording of sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act ( see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) , namely to detain in prison serious offenders who posed a significant risk to members of the public of causing serious harm by the commission of further serious offences until they no longer posed such a risk . He noted that in a previous case the Secretary of ORG had conceded that it would be irrational to have a policy of making release dependent upon the prisoner undergoing a treatment course without making reasonable provision for such courses , and that his position in the present case was that the concession stood . As to the Secretary of ORG ’s contention that the concession did not assist in the present case as it was for ORG to decide whether to release an ORG prisoner , and not for the Secretary of ORG ; and that it was for ORG to decide what evidence satisfied it that an ORG prisoner should be released , he said :

“ DATE . We found [ these ] submissions lacking in realism . Courses are provided because experience shows that these are usually necessary if dangerous offenders are to cease to be dangerous . It is for this reason that performance of the appropriate courses is likely to be a prerequisite to a prisoner satisfying ORG that he has ceased to be dangerous ... The reality is that the possibility for dangerous prisoners both to cease to be dangerous and to show that they have ceased to be dangerous lies largely in the hands of the Secretary of ORG . It has been his policy to provide the necessary courses and to do so within a time scale that gives lifers a chance to demonstrate that they are safe for release by the time that they complete their tariff periods , or reasonably soon thereafter . ”

CARDINAL . Lord PERSON referred to the decision of the Secretary of ORG to bring into force the provisions introducing ORG sentences without having first ensured that there existed the necessary resources to give effect to the policy that would ordinarily have given IPP prisoners a fair chance of demonstrating to ORG , once the time for review arrived , that they were no longer dangerous ( see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) . He continued :

“ CARDINAL . ... This can not simply be regarded as a discretionary choice about resources , which is pre - eminently a matter for the government rather than the courts . We are satisfied that his conduct has been in breach of his public law duty because its direct and natural consequence is to make it likely that a proportion of IPP prisoners will , avoidably , be kept in prison for longer than necessary either for punishment or for protection of the public , contrary to the intention of ORG ( and the objective of LAW which ORG must have been mindful ) . ”

CARDINAL . Having established that the Secretary of ORG had breached his public law duty in failing to provide the necessary courses , the court went on to examine the lawfulness of the continued detention . Lord PERSON indicated that the court could see no answer to the submission of ORG and the Secretary of ORG that the DATE Act made express statutory provision for the circumstances in which ORG prisoners could be released and that ORG judgment would require them to be released in disregard of the express requirements of the LAW . He noted that section CARDINAL of the DATE Act made the release of IPP prisoners subject to the provisions of LAW , section CARDINAL of which provided for the circumstances in which an ORG prisoner had to be released once he had served the tariff period . He considered that it was not possible to describe a prisoner who remained detained in accordance with these provisions as ‘ unlawfully ORG under common law , and that in any event the common law had to give way to the express requirements of the statute .
CARDINAL . Lord PERSON accordingly concluded that ORG prisoners who had completed their tariff terms remained lawfully detained .

CARDINAL . As to whether there was a violation of LAW in Mr James’ case , he distinguished between the role of treatment in changing the prisoner so that he ceased to be dangerous and the opportunity that treatment provided for assessing whether the prisoner was dangerous . He considered that without a sentence plan and monitoring of the prisoner ’s performance against that plan , realistically the outcome of any review by ORG would be a foregone conclusion .
CARDINAL

CARDINAL . Addressing the possibility of a violation of LAW arising on the basis that LAW had been violated , Lord PERSON considered that so long as the prisoner remained dangerous , his detention would be justified under LAW ( a ) whether or not it was subject to timely periodic review that satisfied the requirements of LAW . He noted , however , that if a very lengthy period elapsed without a review , a stage could be reached at which the detention became arbitrary and no longer capable of justification under LAW ( a ) .

CARDINAL . On the question of the compliance with LAW of the continued detention in the applicant ’s case , Lord PERSON noted that the primary object of the ORG sentence was to protect the public , and not to rehabilitate offenders . Accordingly , detention of the applicants would cease to be justified only when the stage was reached that it was no longer necessary for the protection of the public that they be confined , or if so long elapsed without a meaningful review of this question that their detention became disproportionate or arbitrary . He found that this stage had not yet been reached .
CARDINAL . He concluded :

“ DATE . This appeal has demonstrated an unhappy state of affairs . There has been a systemic failure on the part of the Secretary of ORG to put in place the resources necessary to implement the scheme of rehabilitation necessary to enable the relevant provisions of the DATE Act to function as intended . So far as the CARDINAL claimants are concerned the appropriate remedy is limited to declaratory relief . For the reasons that we have given , however , the prevailing situation is likely to result in infringement of article CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and may ultimately also result in infringement of article QUANTITY ) ... ”
CARDINAL . Mr PERSON appealed to ORG against the judgment of ORG . His appeal was eventually joined with the appeals in the cases of PERSON , the second applicant , and PERSON , the third applicant .

CARDINAL . While the appeal was pending , a full ORG review in respect of Mr PERSON took place on DATE . Mr PERSON had still been unable to undertake the recommended courses . ORG had before it , in addition to the hearing dossier : a victim contact report ; ORG ( ORG ) TIME dated DATE ; a report by an external psychologist dated DATE ; a progress report from an ORG Manager , dated DATE ; and a report prepared by the intended supervising probation officer dated DATE . ORG also heard oral evidence .

CARDINAL . At the hearing , Mr PERSON requested his release and undertook to comply with the proposed licence conditions . The Secretary of ORG was of the view that Mr PERSON should remain in closed conditions for the completion of the coursework . ORG noted that a release plan had been constructed for Mr PERSON involving his accommodation at a hostel and further cognitive skills work , relapse prevention work and the completion of the CALM course to be conducted in the community . Following the hearing , ORG directed Mr James’ release on licence , explaining :

“ The panel noted the strong recommendations for your release and therefore took some time to gain an understanding from you of your responses and attitudes ; they were satisfied , within your intellectual boundaries , that you have achieved a level of understanding and insight which mean that you will willingly engage with the careful structure of the ORG hostel which has been outlined for you . The panel recognised that further work is required ... but after careful consideration of all available evidence the panel saw that work as developmental more than core risk reduction and agreed ... that your risk of violent offending has now reached a level such that it could safely be managed within the community ...
In making their decision the panel recognised that their decision was exceptional : however , the reasons for their conclusions have been clearly set out ... ”
CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON was released on licence .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG published its judgment in the CARDINAL linked appeals ( see paragraphs QUANTITY below ) , finding that there had been no violation of LAW or CARDINAL in Mr James’ case .

CARDINAL . Mr PERSON was convicted of the attempted robbery of a taxi driver . He had previous convictions for both violent and acquisitive offences , linked to the misuse of drugs . On DATE he was sentenced at ORG to an ORG sentence with a tariff of DATE , less DATE spent on remand . Pre - sentence reports assessed him at high risk of reconviction but as posing a low risk of causing serious harm save for a medium risk with regard to prison staff .

CARDINAL . In DATE ORG , the local prison where PERSON was at that time detained , reported that he was motivated to address his offending behaviour but was having difficulties in prison and had CARDINAL adjudications against him . The report recommended that he engage in programmes for ORG , ORG , CALM and Victim Awareness . None of these , however , were available to him at ORG .

CARDINAL . Mr Wells’ tariff expired on DATE . ORG hearing was fixed for DATE . However the dossier in his case was not available and was only received by his solicitor and ORG on DATE . As a result , the hearing did not take place . Further ORG hearings were fixed for DATE and CARDINAL DATE but had to be deferred because insufficient ORG members were available . A hearing was subsequently fixed for CARDINAL DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE Mr Wells issued an application for judicial review seeking an order that his case should be heard by ORG forthwith , relying on LAW .

CARDINAL . On DATE , on ORG concession , PERSON made a declaration that Mr Wells’ rights under LAW had been violated and ordered ORG to hear Mr Wells’ case on CARDINAL DATE . He adjourned the judicial review proceedings for evidence to be served and for consideration to be given to whether it would be appropriate to grant any further declaratory relief .
CARDINAL . ORG heard Mr Wells’ case on CARDINAL DATE . However , on CARDINAL DATE it decided not to direct Mr Wells’ release , noting :

“ ... Whilst in custody you have accumulated a number of adjudications both for drug taking and for bad behaviour . You have not undertaken any offence - focussed work . It is fair to say that that is not your fault . There are no appropriate offending behaviour courses at your current prison . The ORG accept your evidence that you would like to undertake such courses . However , this will require your move to another prison , which the prison authorities have failed to arrange ...

In her most recent report your home probation officer states that your risk will remain high until you have satisfactorily completed appropriate courses , such as ORG - ASRO , ORG , CALM and Victim Awareness and Empathy .
In evidence that probation officer urged the panel to release you so that you could undertake these courses in the community subject to strict conditions ...

Unfortunately it is not the remit of ORG to make up for the deficiencies of the prison service . We are charged with a duty not to release life prisoners while their risk of serious offending remains high . Because you have not been able to do any of the appropriate courses you are unable to demonstrate any reduction in risk from the time of your sentence . Because your risk remains high , the ORG can not direct your release as requested . ”

CARDINAL . Following the decision of ORG , the applicant pursued the judicial review proceedings , arguing that his continued detention was unlawful . His case was joined with the case of PERSON . However , at the hearing PERSON Wells’ counsel indicated that she was content to await the delivery of the judgment in PERSON and then put in amended judicial review grounds or seek a fresh judicial review permission if either such course seemed appropriate

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG handed down its judgment in the judicial review proceedings regarding PERSON ( Lord Justice Laws delivering an opinion with which Mr ORG agreed ) . Laws LJ considered that it was clear at the time the DATE Act was passed that there was a settled understanding shared by Government , relevant agencies and professionals that upon the coming into force of the new sentencing provisions , procedures would be put in place to ensure that courses in prison would be available to maximise the opportunity for lifers to demonstrate they were no longer a danger to the public by the time their tariff expired , or as soon as possible thereafter , so as to allow the prisoner ’s release once that was shown . He was of the view that this understanding was a premise of the legislation , and that it was certainly inherent in the way the legislation was intended to work in practice , and to be given effect by the Secretary of ORG ’s policy set out in ORG CARDINAL ( see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) .
CARDINAL . As to the numbers of ORG sentences imposed and the evidence of how the system had operated in practice , he said :

“ CARDINAL . ... Statistics ... show that the number of serving lifers was CARDINAL on DATE ( the DATE Act was passed on DATE ) , CARDINAL on DATE ( s.CARDINAL came into force on CARDINAL April CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL on DATE . Mr PERSON accepts there was an increase in the lifer population of PERCENT in DATE . On DATE there were CARDINAL prisoners serving ORG ( the median tariff for ORG prisoners at DATE was DATE ) . Yet the number of funded first stage and second stage prison places , within the meaning of ORG CARDINAL , has not risen since DATE ( though the number of core offending behaviour courses has risen from CARDINAL in DATE to CARDINAL in DATE ) ...

Mr PERSON [ Deputy Head of ORG at ORG ] believes ... that in present circumstances ORG can deal ‘ ORG with CARDINAL lifers . IPP prisoners with a tariff of DATE are languishing in local prisons where , as Mr PERSON acknowledges ... , there are few offending behaviour programmes ... The stark consequence is that IPP prisoners , or at least a very high proportion of them , at present have no realistic chance of making objective progress , with the assistance of appropriate initiatives within the prison , towards a real reduction or even elimination of their risk factor by the time their tariff expires . ”

CARDINAL . Laws LJ explained that the tariff element of the ORG sentence fulfilled the aims of punishment , while the post - tariff element fulfilled the aim of public protection . He considered that the justification that was required for a prisoner ’s detention after tariff expiry was not at all justified by or at the time of sentence , because the extent to which , or the time for which , the prisoner would remain a danger was unknown at the time of sentence . It could only be ascertained on a continuing basis , by periodic assessment . ORG emphasised that section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(b ) of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) required the sentencing court to assess the presence or absence of danger , and its extent , at the time of sentence , and not at any other time . Accordingly , when sentence was passed it was not to be presumed against the prisoner that he would still be dangerous after his tariff expires , let alone DATE . To the extent that the prisoner remained incarcerated after tariff expiry without any current and effective assessment of the danger he posed , his detention could not be justified and was therefore unlawful .
CARDINAL . Granting Mr PERSON ’s application for judicial review , ORG concluded :

“ CARDINAL . ... The ORG has obtained from ORG legislation to allow – rather , require : the court has no discretion – the indefinite detention of prisoners beyond the date when the imperatives of retributive punishment are satisfied . But this further detention is not arbitrary . It is imposed to protect the public . As soon as it is shown to be unnecessary for that purpose , the prisoner must be released ( see PERSON ) and CARDINAL ) of LAW ) . Accordingly there must be material at hand to show whether the prisoner ’s further detention is necessary or not . Without current and periodic means of assessing the prisoner ’s risk the regime can not work as ORG intended , and the only possible justification for the prisoner ’s further detention is altogether absent . In that case the detention is arbitrary and unreasonable on first principles , and therefore unlawful .

CARDINAL . Such a consequence would not be averted merely by prompt and regular sittings of ORG Periodic reviews by ORG ( or any person or institution ) only have value to the extent that they are informed by up - to - date information as to the prisoner ’s progress . So much is at least required . But so also are measures to allow and encourage the prisoner to progress , for without them the process of review is a meaningless one ... Reducing the risk posed by lifers must be inherent in the legislation ’s purpose , since otherwise the statutes would be indifferent to the imperative that treats imprisonment strictly and always as a last resort . Whether or not the prisoner ceases to present a danger can not be a neutral consideration , in statute or policy . If it were , we would forego any claim to a rational and humane ( and efficient ) prison regime . Thus the existence of measures to allow and encourage the ORG prisoner to progress is as inherent in the justification for his continued detention as are the ORG reviews themselves ; and without them that detention falls to be condemned as unlawful as surely as if there were no such reviews . ”
CARDINAL . An OASys ( Offender Assessment System ) report dated DATE rated PERSON as being at high risk of reconviction and as posing a high risk of harm to the public .
CARDINAL . On DATE Mr Wells was recommended for the same courses as had been recommended DATE previously ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) and which still remained unavailable to him .
CARDINAL . On DATE Mr Wells’ supervisor recorded his “ almost intolerable ” frustration with his lack of progress .

CARDINAL . Mr Wells issued a second judicial review application on DATE , arguing that his continued detention constituted a breach of his rights under LAW and CARDINAL . His case was joined with that of the third applicant in the present case , Mr PERSON .
CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON completed an Alcohol Free Good Life course .
CARDINAL . On DATE Mr PERSON was transferred to ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE Lord Justice PERSON handed down his judgment in the judicial review proceedings involving PERSON and PERSON . He indicated at the outset :

“ CARDINAL . Their cases highlight the fundamental difficulty inherent in ORG sentences where short minimum terms have been imposed . That difficulty has now been recognised by the amendment to the law . That fundamental difficulty was the failure to ensure that there were in place methods not only of timely assessment as to whether a prisoner remained dangerous , but also systems , such as accredited courses which would enable a prisoner to reduce or extinguish his level of dangerousness and to demonstrate that he had done so to the satisfaction of ORG . ”

CARDINAL . Considering the applicants’ Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL complaint , PERSON considered it essential to identify the objectives which were sought to be achieved by the original imposition of the ORG sentence . Like ORG , he indicated that there could be no assumption that , although a prisoner had been regarded as dangerous at the time when the original sentence was imposed , he would remain dangerous throughout his time in prison , although he added that the amount of time which had passed since sentence or the offender ’s behaviour in prison could provide ample justification for such a conclusion .

CARDINAL . Moses LJ emphasised that it was for ORG to assess the danger posed by a prisoner : if ORG was in a position to judge that the prisoner remained a danger , it could not direct his release even if the reason it reached its conclusion was through no fault of the prisoner ’s but rather because the Secretary of ORG had deprived him of the opportunity of reducing his level of dangerousness or of demonstrating that he had ceased to be a danger . He considered that where ORG was entitled on the material before it to reach a conclusion that the prisoner remained a danger , there could be no breach of LAW as the primary objective and rationale for his continued detention remained . However , he contrasted this position with one where , by reason of the lack of course work , ORG could not determine the level of dangerousness . In such circumstances , the justification for continuing to detain him would no longer exist , and there would be a breach of LAW . He concluded that there would have to be clear evidence before the court that the failure to provide courses and opportunity for assessment with up - to - date information had led to a situation where it could safely be concluded either that the prisoner was not a danger or that it could not be ascertained whether he was a danger or not .
CARDINAL . In respect of PERSON , he concluded that there had been no breach of LAW , noting :

“ DATE . ... The evidence shows that PERSON has been frustrated by the lack of progress which was inevitable following the loss of opportunity to go on those courses which he sought to attend . It is dispiriting to record that position when one appreciates that he is still a very young man and was CARDINAL when the sentence was originally passed . But the fact of the matter remains that the evidence before this court is that on assessment he remains at risk of reconviction , a risk assessed as high / medium with some risk of violent offences . Until he undergoes the accredited work , his past , coupled with his prison behaviour , affords what is described as an indication of the nature of the ongoing risk . It requires no imagination to appreciate that the frustration which has led to his bad behaviour in prison has no doubt been aggravated by the fact that he has been unable to undergo the necessary programmes of work . But that of itself does not break the link between the purpose for which the original sentence was passed and his continuing detention . There is no basis for saying that the current level of dangerousness can not be ascertained , and , in those circumstances , no basis for saying that the link between the original sentence and his continued detention has been broken . ”
CARDINAL . However , he found that the continuing failure to provide the relevant courses following the declaration of PERSON amounted to a breach of LAW .
CARDINAL . Mr Wells appealed the finding that there had been no breach of LAW . The Secretary of ORG did not appeal the finding that there had been a breach of LAW .
CARDINAL . Mr Wells subsequently completed the ORG course ( DATE and DATE ) and the ORG course ( MONEY October and DATE ) .

“ DATE . The purpose and justification of a sentence of imprisonment or a similar measure deprivative of liberty is ultimately to protect society against crime .
